ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Discussion: Closing the Archives
ygData.msgSnippet: Ken, Help me out.  I am not sure what you are referring to when you talk about the Archives being open to the public?  Do you mean the Yahoo!Group posting

Ken,

Help me out.  I am not sure what you are referring to when you talk 
about the Archives being open to the public?  Do you mean the 
Yahoo!Group posting archives?  Or is there a documentation and/or files 
archive separate from this Yahoo!Groups forum which I am not recalling 
off the top of my head?

In other words, are you talking about taking this Yahoo!Group private 
and invitation only?  Or perhaps even shutting it down?  I am not clear 
on what is being referenced in your original email as there were no 
links and I could not quite tell what was "in" the mentioned Archives to 
gain sufficient context to know what I was supposed to be evaluating.


Jim


John Arrowwood wrote:

> One other possibility is that in December people went on vacation (so 
> to speak), and nobody has really returned yet...  Thus, nobody has 
> said anything to spark discussion.  I've seen in the past where 
> something happens (or doesn't happen) and that causes stagnation and 
> quiet.  Then later, the noise level starts to rise again, but only 
> when somebody actually starts talking about something that enough 
> people are interested in.
>
> After all, I'm guessing that people don't join inactive lists, so the 
> fact that the list wasn't very active may be the real reason why the 
> new people were so greatly reduced.  Here's an easy way to find out.  
> Leave the archives public for now.  But find a way to spark discussion 
> that gets all the long-time members engaged.  Get the volume of 
> messages back up THAT way, and keep it there for a while, and see if 
> new user rate goes up.
>
> -- John
>
> On 2/22/06, *Kenneth Stanley* <kstanley@... 
> <mailto:kstanley@...>> wrote:
>
>     Hi Everyone,
>
>     I've spoken to Derek James (who runs this group) about this issue,
>     and he suggested I bring it up for discussion.  So please feel free
>     to share your thoughts.
>
>     I have come to the conclusion that opening the archives to public
>     viewing was probably not the best idea in retrospect.  There is one
>     good motivation for doing so, which is that it makes them
>     potentially searchable from outside engines.  However, on balance I
>     believe it is now apparent after we have run this experiment for a
>     couple months that this benefit is outweighed by the downsides:
>
>     In particular I think opening the archives has significantly
>     deterred non-members from joining the group.  The surface-level
>     effect of this deterrence is simply that the group grows less
>     quickly.  However, there is a more concerning secondary effect,
>     which is that when you do not join, you are less likely to post even
>     if you have something worth contributing, because it would require
>     joining to do so.  Therefore, the net effect is stagnant growth and
>     a general squelching of broader discussion and fresh new input from
>     outside.
>
>     I also believe there is a more subtle tertiary effect on existing
>     members, which is that now that you don't need to log into yahoo to
>     view the latest messages, you are more likely not to post something
>     that you think of offhand, because that would require logging in.
>     In the past, since you had to log in in order to view the archives,
>     you were already logged in once ideas popped into your head, but now
>     you are likely not logged in, and therefore it isn't worth going to
>     the trouble just to make a casual point.  I know that I have found
>     even myself falling into that kind of pattern and not posting since
>     I wasn't logged in.  Again, the net effect is muting discussion.
>
>     The statistics appear to back up this theory.  Of course, statistics
>     prove correlation and not causality, but the argument for causality
>     is strenghened by the precise alignment between the time that we
>     opened the archives and the time that membership growth and posting
>     suddenly plummeted.  Here are the numbers:
>
>     New Members by Month
>     --------------------
>     Oct: 11
>     Nov: 14
>     Dec: 5
>     Jan: 4
>     Feb: 3 (so far)
>
>     New Posts by Month
>     ------------------
>     Oct: 76
>     Nov: 77
>     Dec: 25
>     Jan: 38
>     Feb: 22 (so far)
>
>     Both statistics show a sudden and dramatic drop right at December,
>     right about when we opened the archives.  That seems to support the
>     idea that doing so had a negative effect on overall participation.
>     Of course there are other possible explanations such as the natural
>     ebb and flow of discourse or just a general downward trend as people
>     change interests, but the coincidental correlation in timing makes
>     it likely that even if those are true, they probably are not the
>     only contributing factors.
>
>     My view is that this group is first and foremost a discussion group,
>     and only secondarily a reference site.  It's nice to be able to
>     search for old discusison, but what we're really here for is to
>     interact with each other in the present.  Therefore, it doesn't make
>     sense to sacrifice the interactive quality for a slightly more
>     convenient reference, at least in my opinion.
>
>     So I am recommending we close the archives to the public again and
>     return to our old system.  However, since we have been genuinely a
>     thriving community for several years now (just look at most yahoo
>     groups and we are almost unmatched in consistent quality content and
>     friendly discussion), it is only right to let everyone have their
>     two cents before such a decision is made, so we can decide together
>     rather than make a unilateral decision.  Derek will ultimately
>     decide what to do based on your input.  If no one has input, it will
>     just be a decision between myself and Derek, which is fine, but this
>     is your opportunity to participate.
>
>     ken
>
>
